(M = Ca, Sr, and Ba) before and after N
and negative values correspond to the tensile and compressive
strains, respectively. As the temperature increases, generally, a
crystal lattice undergoes tensile stress and expands. It is
generally accepted that under the tensile stress, the lattice
vibrations and/or the formation of defects force the phosphors
more easily to promote nonradiative relaxation.
presumed that the enhancement of PL intensity is ascribed to
the compensation of the thermally induced tensile stress by the
compressive stress due to the N
(M = Ca, Sr, and Ba) phosphors. The fact that the PL
intensities of the two phosphors (for Ca and Sr) remarkably
not changed, corroborates the structural strain eﬀect on the PL
). Evidently, for Ca and Sr, the
stronger absorption bands between 300 and 500 nm are
doping, while for Ba, the absorption bands
are nearly same before and after N
compressive strain plays an important role in the eﬀective
transfer of the absorbed energy from the host lattice to the
activator ion even though the diﬀerence of strain values before
doping is very small, resulting in the enhanced
